entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: Pew Research Center conducted this study to understand how Americans voted in 2024 and how their turnout and vote choices differed from 2016 and 2020. For this analysis, we surveyed 8,942 U.S. citizens ages 18 and older who are members of the Centerâ€™s American Trends Panel (ATP). We verified their turnout in the five general [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals: Research team Jocelyn Kiley, Director, Political ResearchScott Keeter, Senior Survey AdvisorHannah Hartig, Senior ResearcherBaxter Oliphant, Senior ResearcherGabe Borelli, Research AssociateAndrew Daniller, Research AssociateAndy Cerda, Research AnalystJoseph Copeland, Research AnalystTed Van Green, Research AnalystShanay Gracia, Research Assistant Communications and editorial [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Demographic profiles of Trump and Harris voters in 2024
entry.summary: The composition of Republican and Democratic voters in the United States has changed since the 2020 presidential election, and the shifts have been even larger since the 2016 contest. Donald Trumpâ€™s voters overall were more racially and ethnically diverse in 2024 than in his prior campaigns, reflecting gains among Hispanic, Black and Asian voters. Conversely, [â€¦] The post 3. Demographic profiles of Trump and Harris voters in 2024 appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Voting patterns in the 2024 election
entry.summary: For the most part, voting patterns across demographic groups in the 2024 presidential election were not substantially different from the 2020 and 2016 elections. But Donald Trumpâ€™s gains among several key groups of voters proved decisive in his 2024 victory. To explore voting patterns among subgroups over time, refer to detailed tables. Hispanic voters were [â€¦] The post 2. Voting patterns in the 2024 election appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Voter turnout, 2020-2024
entry.summary: Because partisanship and voting preference are highly correlated â€“ and most adults stick with their preferred party over time â€“ voter turnout is often a key factor in understanding why there are changes in electoral outcomes year to year. In the 2024 presidential election, a higher share of Donald Trumpâ€™s 2020 voters than Joe Bidenâ€™s [â€¦] The post 1. Voter turnout, 2020-2024 appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Behind Trumpâ€™s 2024 Victory, a More Racially and Ethnically Diverse Voter Coalition
entry.summary: Pew Research Centerâ€™s in-depth study of its survey respondents who voted in the 2024 election examines turnout, voting patterns and demographics. The post Behind Trumpâ€™s 2024 Victory, a More Racially and Ethnically Diverse Voter Coalition appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Millions remain invisible â€“ but Asia-Pacific leaders pledge change by 2030
entry.summary: More than a decade after Asian and Pacific nations launched a campaign to ensure every life is counted, millions across the region still remain â€œinvisibleâ€ â€“ born, living, and dying without formal recognition.

entry.title: Upcoming elections â€˜crucial opportunityâ€™ for Central African Republic, UN top official tells Security Council
entry.summary: As the Central African Republic (CAR) prepares for upcoming elections, the country continues to grapple with a fragile security and humanitarian context, the UN Security Council heard on Thursday.

entry.title: Ukraine: Increasing hostilities displace civilians, limit humanitarian access
entry.summary: Deadly hostilities continued along the front-line regions of Ukraine on Wednesday, displacing civilians and damaging civilian infrastructure, the UN has reported.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Conflictâ€™s survivors have been through hell, says UN aid chief
entry.summary: The conflict-impacted people of the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) urgently need much more international assistance than they are getting today, the UNâ€™s top aid official said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: It wasnâ€™t an average Thursday morning in Manhattan. In the early hours, UN diplomats (and UN News) hit the streets in their sneakers â€“ from Times Square to East River â€“ following a route that traced the shape of â€œUN@80â€.

entry.title: UN calls for restraint after deadly Kenya protests
entry.summary: The UN is monitoring the situation in Kenya in the wake of deadly antigovernment protests on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights office sounds the alarm over forced displacement in the West Bank
entry.summary: Palestinians in the occupied West Bank, including East Jerusalem, are increasingly being subjected to forced displacement and land seizures, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, has reported.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Our kids cry for foodâ€™: Most families in Gaza survive on one meal a day
entry.summary: Most families in the Gaza Strip are surviving on one meal a day and one-third go entire days without eating as a result of Israelâ€™s continued bombardment of the enclave, according to the UN World Food Programme (WFP) and partners.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Despite the fall of Assad, the illicit drug trade in Syria is far from over
entry.summary: When Bashar Al-Assad ruled Syria, his regime was widely accused of profiting from the production and trafficking of Captagon, an illicit synthetic drug that is most commonly abused by users in the Middle East.

entry.title: Video: How do American men and women differ religiously?
entry.summary: The gender gap in American religion is shrinking. Historically, women have been more religious than men. But the gap is smaller than it once was. The post Video: How do American men and women differ religiously? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Spirituality and Religion: How Does the U.S. Compare With Other Countries?
entry.summary: Explore how adults in the U.S. and 35 other countries compare religiously and spiritually when it comes to affiliation, prayer, afterlife beliefs and more. The post Spirituality and Religion: How Does the U.S. Compare With Other Countries? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How to plan a trip to see Africa's Great Migration
entry.summary:
Africaâ€™s Great Migration is a world-renowned wildlife phenomenon where more than a million wildebeest, along with countless zebras and gazelles, follow the rains across Tanzaniaâ€™s Serengeti and Kenyaâ€™s Maasai Mara in a relentless quest for greener pastures. Each year, Africaâ€™s Great Migration sees millions of wildebeest and zebra thunder across the sun-bleached savannah, drawn by instinct to cross crocodile-infested rivers where predators lie in wait. But beyond the chaos, this epic journey reveals a deeper, more complex tale of survival and symbiosis on the Serengeti stage.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
To a soundtrack of thundering hooves and panicked brays, wildebeest plunge into the muddy Mara River, churning the water as sly crocodilesâ€¦

entry.title: The small Swiss town where people still vote by hands in the air
entry.summary:
For most of the year, big crowds are unusual in the Swiss town of Glarus. At the base of a dramatic point in the Alps called the GlÃ¤rnisch ridge, the hamlet is tranquil, largely undisturbed by the tourists who descend on the regionâ€™s picturesque areas. But every year there is one dayâ€”usually the first Sunday in Mayâ€”where citizens of the canton gather en masse in the town square for a tradition thatâ€™s over 700 years old. Questions are boomed over the loudspeakers and thousands of people raise their hands in response. This is the Landsgemeindeâ€”one of the world's oldest forms of direct democracy still in practice.Â Â
Meaning â€œcantonal community assemblyâ€ in German, the Landsgemeinde dates back to medieval times. Glarus, with its population of around 41,000 people, is one of only two Swissâ€¦

entry.title: Why Romeâ€™s dolphins are fighting each other
entry.summary:
Rome, the Eternal City, is revered for its history, art, culture, and food. Yet, few people know that less thanÂ an hour away, where the Tiber River flows into the Tyrrhenian Sea, thereâ€™s something that makes the area even more unique: a population of around 500 bottlenose dolphins.Â
Now, aÂ recent studyÂ shows that the dolphins are not only sick, but theyâ€™re fighting over foodâ€”and itâ€™s due to human activity.Â
The â€œCapitoline dolphins,â€ as researchers have named them, have inhabited the coast outside Rome for thousands of years, as shown by mosaics from the archaeological site of Ostia Antica that depict the dolphins stealing fish from fishermen's nets 2,000 years ago. Yet theyâ€™ve only recently been closely studied, beginning in 2016.Â Two male dolphins have an aggressive encoâ€¦

entry.title: Why this photographer made a camera lens out of glacial ice
entry.summary:
Artist Tristan Duke traveled to Svalbard, Norway, in 2022 to create camera lenses made from shards of pristine ice pulled from glacial waters. Tristan Duke uses Arctic ice and a unique technique to offer a fresh perspective on a world transformed by climate change.
Glacial ice is formed fromÂ snow accumulating and compacting over millennia. As the pressure increases, crystalline layers are smoothed into one of the clearest substances found in nature. That alchemyâ€”and the knowledge that climate change is causing glaciers to rapidly disappearâ€”inspired 44-year-old artist Tristan Duke to create a photo lens out of glacial ice. â€œI just felt this real sense of urgency,â€ Duke says. He wanted to capture a glacier through its own â€œeye,â€ as he puts it, like a self-portrait.
In the spring of 2022, Duke hauled hundreds of pounds of gear to Svalbard, Norway, including a giant tent camera that he designed himself and molds for shaping the ice into lenses. The tent functioned like a camera obscura: Duke would place a palm-size piece of ice in a hole in the canvas, projecting an image of the landscape inside the tent that would then be captured on a 42-by-100-inch negative.
Some of the photographs were clearer than he expected, but as the lenses melted, the accumulation of water produced its own effect. â€œPeople have told me that it looks like the world blurred through tears,â€ he says.
To contrast this Arctic sublime against a world on fire, he traveled through the American West to document wildfires and energy infrastructure with lenses created from locally sourced ice. He wants to invert the romantic gaze. â€œWe see a sort of fragile nature bearing witness to the unbridled and cataclysmic power of the human world.â€ undefined undefined A version of this story appears in the July 2025 issueÂ ofÂ National GeographicÂ magazine.

entry.title: Britainâ€™s first Black queen? The real story of Queen Charlotte
entry.summary:
When 17-year-old Sophia Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz caught her first glimpse of the London palace that was to be her home in 1761, she turned pale. She was set to become Queen of Great Britain and Ireland within hours, but she had never set foot in England or met her husband-to-be.
What happened next is the stuff of royal history, brought to recent light in Netflixâ€™s limited series, Queen Charlotte: a Bridgerton Story fictionalizing the life of the timid German girl rumored to have been Britainâ€™s first Black queen. But who was the real Queen Charlotte?
Born in 1744 in Mecklenburg-Strelitz, a duchy in what is now northern Germany, the princess had an unremarkable childhood in what other members of the European aristocracy considered to be a mediocre and provincial dukedom.â€¦

entry.title: Try a detour on your next trip to these classic destinations
entry.summary:
Philadelphia's Magic Gardens is an art gallery meets community center on South Street. Detour destinations, aka lesser-known spots, are trending in travel for several reasons. Try one of these getaways that are less crowded and offer rich local experiences.
A recent Expedia travel trends report shows that, remarkably, 63 percent of travelers plan to include lesser-known spots in their travels this year, with destinations that offer locally rich experiences.
A detour destination doesnâ€™t mean completely avoiding a popular destination. It can also involve a night or two in that tried-and-true destination, just with an alternate destination also worked into the plans, for reasons including lower costs and new experiences.
Just 15 minutes from busy Monterey, Carmel-by-thâ€¦

entry.title: Visiting Istanbul? Hereâ€™s where to eat
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Thereâ€™s no shortage of good reasons to visit Istanbul â€” from its flagship attractions such as the Hagia Sophia and the Basilica Cistern to the seductive rhythms of its busier neighbourhoods and the tranquillity of its islands. Yet its standout feature is arguably its cuisine. This is a city thatâ€™s been home to an impressive, bustling dining scene for over two millennia â€” and, while many travellers limit themselves to the prix fixe menus in the Historical Peninsula, thereâ€™s a greater culinary depth available to those willing to venture beyond the touristy kebab shops. Here are nine of the cityâ€™s best dining options â€” restaurants that excite the locals and offer visitors something theyâ€™re unlikely to forget. Â
â€¦

entry.title: How to lower stress in 5 minutes
entry.summary:
Feeling overwhelmed? Youâ€™re not alone. Between meetings, errands, and the endless scroll of everyday life, stress builds up fastâ€”and it doesnâ€™t just take a toll on your mood. It can disrupt your sleep, spike your heart rate, and weaken your immune system.
But hereâ€™s the good news: research shows that even small, low-effort actions can help your body reset. Here are six things you can do right nowâ€”and the science behind why they work.
Few things affect your nervous system as immediatelyâ€”or as powerfullyâ€”as your breath. Studies show that deep breathing can lower blood pressure, slow your heart rate, and boost heart rate variabilityâ€”a key marker of resilience. It also reduces cortisol, the stress hormone associated with a range of issues, including poor sleep and brain fog. Controâ€¦

entry.title: An LED track, super shoes, and a suit made from Aeronodes
entry.summary:
7.65 seconds.Â
Thatâ€™s the amount of time that Kenyan Faith Kipyegon needs to shave from her world record time in order to become the first woman to run the mile in under 4 minutes.Â Â
Kipyegon, a three-time gold medalist, has spent months training for an exhibition on Thursday in Paris where sheâ€™ll take a crack at the mythic sub-four barrier. An attempt, she says, to â€œcement her legacy.â€Â Â Â
The event, dubbed Breaking4, is being staged by Nike, Kipyegon's sponsor. To help her make history, everyone from physiologists to shoe designers have rallied to find ways to help her trim every hundredth of a second possibleâ€”some of which make the run ineligible for official world records.Â Â
Itâ€™s a tricky task. The mile is short enough that small benefits have little time to accrete â€¦

entry.title: UN urges renewed diplomacy on Iran nuclear deal, hails Tehran-Tel Aviv ceasefire as â€˜significant achievementâ€™
entry.summary: A fragile ceasefire brokered by the United States between Iran and Israel appears to be holding, marking a tentative halt to a dangerous regional escalation that included airstrikes, retaliatory missile attacks and mounting civilian casualties.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Bold new initiative aims to strengthen and improve the UN, senior officials tell Member States
entry.summary: Member States heard on Tuesday how the UN is progressing with a new plan to ensure the world body remains effective, cost-efficient and responsive to the billions of people it serves.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Aftermath of Tripoli clashes puts Libyaâ€™s fragile stability to the test
entry.summary: Libya once again stands at a critical juncture in its political transition, after armed clashes erupted in Tripoli last month, further destabilising the country, the UN Special Representative for the country told the Security Council on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: TÃ¼rk speaks out on sexual violence, Brazil floods update, Nicaraguan human rights violations
entry.summary: Gender-based violence is rising - especially in conflict â€“ something which is a â€œshameless repudiation of the basic rules of warfare,â€ according to the UN human rights chiefÂ Volker TÃ¼rk.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Still reelingâ€™: Myanmar quakes worsen humanitarian crisis in fractured country
entry.summary: Nearly three months after Myanmarâ€™s strongest earthquake in a century, more than six million people remain in urgent need of assistance, as the disaster compounds a humanitarian crisis driven by years of conflict, political turmoil and mass displacement.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Political Affairs chief hails Iran-Israel ceasefire as â€˜significant achievementâ€™
entry.summary: The Security Council is meeting over the future of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action put in place in 2015 to prevent Iran from weaponising its ambitious nuclear programme, which has been in effective limbo since the US withdrawal in 2018 and Iranâ€™s rejection of parts of the deal. UN political affairs chief Rosemary DiCarlo described the US-brokered ceasefire overnight between Israel and Iran as a â€œsignificant achievementâ€ and â€œan opportunity to avoid a catastrophic escalation and achieve a peaceful resolution of the Iran nuclear issue.â€ Follow our Meetings Coverage Section live coverage below and UN News app users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Power to the people; funding community-led development in Somalia
entry.summary: A story of grassroots persistence in Somalia could serve as a powerful reminder of the impact of innovative financing mechanisms as the international community meets in Spain to discuss how to fund global sustainable development.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Resettlement changed her life. Now sheâ€™s fighting for others to have the same chance
entry.summary: Once a teenager without legal status or access to education, Madiha Ali Changezi is now speaking out as a living example of what refugee resettlement can achieve.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres urges Iran and Israel to â€˜fully respectâ€™ ceasefire
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Tuesday welcomed the ceasefire announcement between Iran and Israel which was announced on social media overnight by US President Donald Trump.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Over 400 Palestinians killed around private aid hubs, UN rights office says
entry.summary: At least 410 Palestinians have been killed by the Israeli military while trying to fetch from controversial new aid hubs in Gaza â€“ a likely war crime â€“ the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: What time is it on the Moon? Itâ€™s all relativeâ€¦
entry.summary: Telling the time on the Moon is more complicated than you might think, but answering the question is becoming more important amid a resurgent interest in lunar exploration. The UN is helping to ensure the Moon is governed in a coordinated and peaceful way, and agreeing on a time zone is a central element of international discussions.

entry.title: Taliban bride
entry.summary: Women in Afghanistan are prisoners in their own homes. This is the story of Marjan, married at 12 to a Taliban fighter - by Zala & Asad Nariman Read at Aeon

entry.title: Dine like in The Bear at these Chicago fine dining spots
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
From beef sandwiches to Michelin-star-seeking menus â€” TV show The Bearâ€™s fictional restaurant has given us a story arc that, in many ways, mirrors the real-life culinary history of the city itâ€™s set in. Just as the Original Beef of Chicagoland was transformed from a sauce-splattered sandwich bar into the showâ€™s titular fine-dining venture, so too has Chicago evolved from a meatpacking capital to one of Americaâ€™s pioneering food cities.
One upon a time, fine dining in the Windy City mostly consisted of steak and potatoes. Then in 1987, Charlie Trotter opened his eponymous restaurant in Lincoln Park. Using French and Japanese techniques and lots of fresh vegetables, Trotter â€” like The Bearâ€™s chef, Carmy â€” was determiâ€¦

entry.title: What is a heat dome? The science behind the weather phenomenon
entry.summary:
A sunbather rests in a chair in a park in Sutton Place, New York in 2013. This summerâ€™s heat dome will bring triple-digit temperatures to millions of Americans. Extreme humidity and triple-digit temperatures are affecting around 250 million people across the United States. Here's the science behind the heat dome thatâ€™s stifling the nation.
  SummerÂ is officially here, and itâ€™s kicking off with an extreme heat dome thatâ€™s scorching much of the Central and Eastern United States.Â  â€œA strong upper-level ridge parked over the eastern half of the country will continue to generate an extremely dangerous heat wave this week,â€ the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration'sÂ National Weather Service warns.Â  High temperatures in the 100s are expected to break records, â€¦

entry.title: How a 102-year-old neurologist keeps his brain sharp
entry.summary:
According to neurologist Howard Tucker, there is a scientific basis for not retiring. That's why this 102-year-old is the world's oldest practicing doctor. Howard Tucker has been practicing medicine since 1947. Ahead of his 103rd birthday, the neurologist shares his thoughts on living a healthier lifeâ€”and enjoying it, too.
At 102 years old, Howard Tucker is the worldâ€™s oldest practicing doctorâ€”and heâ€™s eagerly looking for new work since the hospital where he taught medical residents closed in 2022. â€œRight now, Iâ€™m out of a job,â€ Tucker says.
While heâ€™s no longer seeing patients, Tuckerâ€™s resume speaks for itself. He received his medical doctorate in 1947 and completed his neurology residency in 1953. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II and was the chief neurologist â€¦

entry.title: Humidity really has gotten worse in the last 40 years
entry.summary:
The sun rises behind the skyline of midtown Manhattan and the Empire State Building in New York City. This summer's high humidity is expected to be even worse in urban areas. As temperatures rise across the U.S., hereâ€™s what you need to know about high humidity and how it can affect you.
The first major heat wave of summer has enveloped much of the midwestern and eastern U.S. in a brutal â€œdomeâ€ of record temperatures and high humidity. The dome phenomenon happens when weather conditions cause high pressure to remain stagnant, trapping bands of heat and humidity within a region for long periods of time.
Experts warn that heat-related illness, including heat exhaustion and heat stroke, pose significant risks over the coming days.
Itâ€™s no surprise that summerâ€™s high temperaâ€¦

entry.title: Alaskaâ€™s untamed wilderness is about to get more accessible
entry.summary:
The Alaska Cabins Project aims to make traveling to Alaska's wilderness easier and more inclusive. A new project in the Chugach and Tongass National Forests will make overnights in Alaskaâ€™s wilderness less intimidating for travelers looking for â€œsoftâ€ adventures in the wild.
Overnighting in Alaskaâ€™s wilderness is about to get easier. The Alaska Cabins Project, a joint initiative from the Forest Service and the National Forest Foundation, will bring 25 new, easily reachable abodes to the untamed Tongass and Chugach national forests by 2027. Several have already openedâ€”or will openâ€”this year.
The project marks a milestone for the state. â€œThis is the largest expansion of public use cabins on Alaskaâ€™s national forests in 50 years,â€ says Patrick Shannon, the NFFâ€™s Pacific Northwestâ€¦

entry.title: The improbable city where ice cream is king
entry.summary:
When Shahrukh Shah was a boy, the small, dusty city of Gangapur, India, wasnâ€™t known for much. It was an agricultural town, a hub for the regionâ€™s many farmers, and Shahâ€™s family grew corn and wheat on three acres nearby. But farming was never easy on the plains of central Rajasthanâ€”Indiaâ€™s largest state and among its driestâ€”and as Shah got older, it became tougher still, with the rainy seasons more erratic, droughts more frequent, and water for irrigation harder to come by.
Then, around 2014, when Shah was a teenager, his father decided to give up farming during the parched four-month summer in favor of the business that has since put Gangapur on the map: ice cream.
(8 ice cream styles from around the world.) https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngm-2507-India-ice-câ€¦

author.name: Brian Kevin, Federico Borella, Michela Balboni

entry.title: 7 of the best bookshops to visit in the UK
entry.summary:
This port town indie store includes a â€˜studyâ€™ with co-working desks and an upstairs cafe. Independent Bookshop Week was celebrated across the UK this June â€” weâ€™ve selected four shops worth a literary pilgrimage.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With summer bringing Independent Bookshop week to UK shores, weâ€™re celebrating bookstores that are well worth travelling to. From a hilltop spot in York to a cool cafe hangout in Londonâ€™s East End and far beyond, weâ€™ve selected independently run shops that continue to draw book-lovers to towns and cities across the UK and Ireland. Many of these have been recognised by the Independent Bookshop of the Year award, past or present, and all are lovely places to linger over a good read, graphic novel or openâ€¦

entry.title: This city rewards travelersâ€”just for being responsible
entry.summary:
Responsible travelers are rewarded through the fairly new CopenPay program after they engage in good deeds such as picking up trash in one of Copenhagenâ€™s green spaces. With overtourism concerns hitting cities across Europe, this new initiative aims to encourage eco-friendly behavior by offering free or discounted food, drinks, and cultural experiences.
Imagine a city that rewards you for making sustainable choicesâ€”ride a bike instead of driving to receive free admission to a museum, walk 5,000 steps to get a free cup of coffee, or collect trash from the harbor to earn a free kayak ride. Thatâ€™s what Copenhagen is doing through its new CopenPay initiative.
CopenPay encourages visitors to make environmentally friendly choices in exchange for free or discounted local experiences,â€¦

entry.title: What was the Scopes 'Monkey' Trial?
entry.summary:
Jock the monkey listens in on the Scopes 'Monkey' trial verdict in Washington DC on July 21, 1923. The Scopes trial was one of the most covered court cases in US history, and the first US trial to be broadcast on national radio. In 1925, a small-town trial became a national spectacle, pitting faith against science. Here's what to know about the lasting legacy of the Scopes 'Monkey' Trial.
Was Charles Darwinâ€™s theory of evolution scientific fact or dangerous, anti-Christian heresy? In 1925, one young teacher became a target of a law outlawing teaching evolution in schoolsâ€”and a central figure in the fight to teach evidence-based science.Â
Twenty-four-year-old John T. Scopes didnâ€™t remember if heâ€™d actually taught evolution to his high school students in Rhea County, Tennesseeâ€”â€¦

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Moira Fagan, Research AssociateSneha Gubbala, Research AnalystJacob Poushter, Associate Director, Global Attitudes Research Dorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystJonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherJanell Fetterolf, Senior ResearcherShannon Greenwood, Digital [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Centerâ€™s Spring 2025 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on a mix of telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates and Social Research Centre. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Read more about our international survey methodology and [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix: Classifying European political parties
entry.summary: Classifying parties as populist Although experts generally agree that populist political leaders or parties display high levels of anti-elitism, definitions of populism vary. We use three measures to classify populist parties: anti-elite ratings from the 2019 Chapel Hill Expert Survey (CHES), Norrisâ€™ Global Party Survey and The PopuList. We define a party as populist when [â€¦] The post Appendix: Classifying European political parties appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Views of Zelenskyy
entry.summary: Across 25 countries, a median of 45% have confidence in Zelenskyy, while an identical share do not. Ratings vary widely, from 85% confidence in Sweden to 19% in Greece. The post 3. Views of Zelenskyy appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of Russia and Putin
entry.summary: Across 25 countries, a median of 79% view Russia unfavorably and 84% lack confidence in Putin. Opinions differ by age, ideology and right-wing populist party support. The post 2. Views of Russia and Putin appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views of NATO
entry.summary: Majorities in 10 of 13 member nations surveyed have a positive view of NATO, though ratings have dipped in a few countries since last year. The post 1. Views of NATO appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: NATO Viewed Favorably Across 13 Member Nations
entry.summary: Ahead of the June 2025 NATO summit, international views of Putin and Russia remain negative, while Zelenskyy gets mixed ratings overall. The post NATO Viewed Favorably Across 13 Member Nations appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: These are the first images from Earthâ€™s giant new telescope
entry.summary:
Perched high in the foothills of Chileâ€™s Andes mountains, a revolutionary new space telescope has just taken its first pictures of the cosmosâ€”and theyâ€™re spectacular.Â
Astronomers are excited about the first test images released from the Vera C. Rubin Observatory, which show the universe in unprecedented detail, from violent cosmic collisions to faraway nebulas.
â€œIt's really a great instrument. Its depth and large field of view will allow us to take really nice images of stars, especially faint ones,â€ says Christian Aganze, a galactic archeologist at Stanford University who will use the observatoryâ€™s data to study the formation and evolution of the Milky Way. â€œWe are truly entering a new era.â€
The observatory has a few key components: A giant telescope, called the Simonyi Suâ€¦

entry.title: Why Puerto Rico should be your next food destination
entry.summary:
Puerto Rico imports 85% of its food â€” an issue that became even more apparent after Hurricane Maria. â€œTeaching people how to grow food, for us, thatâ€™s a rebel act,â€ says EfrÃ©n David Robles, owner of small, family-run farm Frutos Del Guacabo. The Caribbean islandâ€™s cuisine combines African, Indigenous and Spanish influences to create dishes of distinction.
More than 500 years of complex history shines through in Puerto Ricoâ€™s cuisine â€” a dynamic mix of Spanish, African and Indigenous culinary traditions. Many of Puerto Ricoâ€™s most famous dishes focus on hearty starches, like plantain and yuca, infused with the herby flavours of the islandâ€™s favourite condiment, sofrito. Restaurants across the historic capital, San Juan, give a fine-dining twist to classic dishes such as tostonâ€¦

entry.title: UN80 Initiative: What it is â€“ and why it matters to the world
entry.summary: In a world grappling with growing crises, deepening inequalities, and eroding trust in global institutions, the United Nations has launched an ambitious effort to strengthen how it serves people everywhere. The UN80 Initiative, unveiled in March by Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres, is a system-wide push to streamline operations, sharpen impact, and reaffirm the UNâ€™s relevance for a rapidly changing world.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 80 years later, the UN Charter is a â€˜living miracle,â€™ Secretary-General says
entry.summary: In front of a multimedia exhibit at United Nations Headquarters entitled â€œReviving the Spirit of San Francisco,â€ Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres welcomed home the UN Charter which was signed in 1945 in the Californian city.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres condemns Iran attack on US airbase in Qatar
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres is â€œdeeply alarmedâ€ by the further escalation of the conflict in the Middle East, his Spokesperson said in a statement on Monday.

entry.title: Bearing the brunt of war: UNICEF chief meets some of Sudanâ€™s 700,000 child refugees crossing into Chad
entry.summary: Since fighting erupted in Sudan in April 2023, more than two million children have been displaced by the brutal war between rival militaries there.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Human Rights Council hears concerns over displacement, genocide risks and migrant trafficking
entry.summary: On day six of theÂ 59th Session of the Human Rights Council (HRC) in Geneva, the Council heard urgent updates on rising internal displacement driven by organised crime, escalating genocide risks and the trafficking of women in the domestic work sector.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tobacco control efforts protect three-quarters of the worldâ€™s population, WHO report finds
entry.summary: Tobacco use still claims over seven million lives a year, the World Health Organization warned on Monday, calling for greater efforts to limit its use amid rising interference from the global tobacco industry.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Senior envoy warns Iran-Israel conflict is deepening crisis in Afghanistan
entry.summary: Afghanistan is already grappling with immense humanitarian and economic challenges and growing instability in the wider region following airstrikes by Israel and the United States in Iran is compounding the situation, the UNâ€™s top envoy in the country told the Security Council on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN condemns â€˜heinousâ€™ terrorist attack at Damascus church that killed dozens
entry.summary: The United Nations has condemned a suicide bombing on Sunday at a Damascus church that killed at least 25 worshippers, including women and children during mass, as a â€œheinous crimeâ€.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Asia is warming twice as fast as the rest of the world
entry.summary: In April 2024, China broke the average temperature record that month. The following month, it was the same - and then again in August. And September. And November.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen: Nearly half the population facing acute food insecurity in some southern areas
entry.summary: The food security situation in Government-controlled areas of southern Yemen is dire, with nearly half the population facing acute food insecurity and struggling to find their next meal.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Iran-Israel crisis: IAEA chief calls for access to damaged nuclear sites
entry.summary: After surprise US bombing raids on Iranian uranium enrichment facilities over the weekend, the head of the UN-backed nuclear watchdog on Monday appealed for immediate access to the targeted sites to assess the damage that is likely â€œvery significantâ€.

entry.title: For the UK's best fish and chips, look no further than Cornwall
entry.summary:
Today, Cornwall's fish and chips offering ranges from beloved local chippies to Michelin-acclaimed kitchens. A crisp portion of fish and chips remains the ultimate coastal comfort food â€” and Cornwall is home to some of the UKâ€™s best, available at everything from traditional chippies to pioneering Michelin-recognised restaurants.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Come summer, nothing quite hits the spot like a generous serving of fish and chips eaten beside the Cornish coast. Whether wrapped in vinegar-soaked paper â€” perhaps enjoyed on a harbour wall â€” or served in a pub garden accompanied by a chilled local cider, this iconic British dish never fails to satisfy. Traditionally made with cod or haddock, deep-fried to a golden crisp and paired witâ€¦

entry.title: Where to go for a beginner's gravel-biking adventure in Scotland
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Galloway is a bit of Scotland thatâ€™s often overlooked by visitors. Across the border from England, this southwestern region (officially Dumfries and Galloway) is often bypassed in the rush north: to Glasgow, Loch Lomond & The Trossachs National Park, and the Highlands. Yet, the place couldnâ€™t be more Scottish. This was the stomping ground of Robert the Bruce and William Wallace. Its wee towns are practical and unfussy, and there are castles left over from the English wars. The scenery â€” mountains ballooning from heather moors, swathes of pine forest, streams where otters tumble â€” has grandeur, sweep and romance. Put it all together, and itâ€™s no surprise the area has caught the eye of travellers on gravel bikes, an incrâ€¦

entry.title: Explore Italy's most famous coastline with these timeless adventures
entry.summary:
Italy's most sought-after destination is ripe for exploring â€” you just have to know where to look. From a clifftop walking trail to a subterranean Roman villa, via a martini worthy of a film star â€” hereâ€™s how to make the most of your time on Italyâ€™s prettiest shoreline.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A landscape of extreme verticality, where gelato-hued houses and terraced gardens cling to sea-facing cliffs, this strip of Southern Italy is justly famed for its beauty. Long a source of inspiration for writers and artists â€” from 19th-century composer Richard Wagner to Patricia Highsmith, who set her novel The Talented Mr Ripley here â€” the entire area is a designated UNESCO World Heritage Site. Ravello, Amalfi and Positano are its most celebraâ€¦

entry.title: GIJN Co-Hosts International Journalists at IRE25
entry.summary: Sixty journalists from more than two-dozen countries and territories attended the International Luncheon at the 2025 Investigative Reporters and Editors Conference.

entry.title: The city of 700 languages
entry.summary:
Seke is an endangered language originally spoken in five villages of northern Nepal, but its future may depend on a handful of vertical villages: apartment buildings in the middle of Brooklyn, New York.â€¯â€¯
How did a little-documented, oral-only language used by no more than 700 people in the high Himalaya come to the concrete jungle? Rasmina Gurung, in her 20s one of Sekeâ€™s youngest speakers, learned the language from her grandmother in the village but soon moved to the countryâ€™s capital, Kathmandu, and eventually New Yorkâ€”where she estimates at least a quarter of her people have ended up. Here they join speakers of dozens of other endangered languages from across the Himalaya, all forming new communities while getting by in an ever evolving mix of Nepali, Tibetan, English, and their oâ€¦

entry.title: Try these essential dishes on your next trip to Greece
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Greek food sings of the summer â€” itâ€™s best enjoyed outside, from mainland mountaintops to island beaches. Mezze spreads celebrate punchy purple olives, garlicky dips and herb-sprinkled cheese, while salads of sun-ripened tomatoes, tangy feta and fragrant oregano are perfect with just-landed grilled fish or slow-stewed legumes cooked in outdoor ovens following recipes that date back to antiquity. Here are the nine essential dishes to try when in Greece. Lily Bellos sits at her Corfu home in Benitses as she showcases her pastitsada, or â€˜la pastizzadaâ€™, as the islandâ€™s Venetian colonisers called it. It's a dish thatâ€™s been representative of Corfu for hundreds of years. Pastitsada is slow-cooked meat â€” beef, rabbit,â€¦

entry.title: Transylvania may hold the secret to a long and happy life
entry.summary: On a chilly twilit evening,Â three men sit around a wood table in the parsonage of a 13th-century church in Transylvania. Outside are ducks, beehives, and a shaggy white dog that we can hear barking at something in the growing dark. Warmed by a wood-burning stove, the men sip tea and nibble savory, pretzel-shaped cookies, and talk about their home, KarÃ¡csonyfalva. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngm-2207-romanian-village-map/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Transylvania. Is there a better known place-name and a lesser known place? (Perhaps Timbuktu.) Even when all of Europe was wilder, Transylvania stood for its wildest edge. This is why Bram Stoker saw fit to use it as a setting forÂ Dracula,Â despite never setting foot there. Itâ€™s a place where Saxons, Huns, Turks, Tartâ€¦

entry.title: Statin drugs are an Internet villain. Do they deserve it?
entry.summary:
The cholesterol-lowering drug Simvastatin. Like other statins, this drug reduces the levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the body. Over 40 million Americans currently take statins. Cholesterol-lowering medicines are some of the most commonly prescribed, effective drugs. Influencers on TikTok have other ideas.
Inside the average doctorâ€™s office, statins arenâ€™t controversial; theyâ€™re a crucial lifesaving tool used to lower dangerously high cholesterol levels, reducing risk of heart attack. But on social media, the drug is often villainized, painted as a poison pill, or a symptom of a diseased medical system. Recently, influencers have claimed that statins cause more harm than good and have endless side effects. Others take even bigger swings, claiming that theÂ funâ€¦

entry.title: What fracking is doing to the Earthâ€”and to our bodies
entry.summary: A methane gas flare erupts at the Bakken Oil Fields in Mountrail County, North Dakota. Research attributes 40% of this centuryâ€™s atmospheric methane increase to fracking. Beneath layers of ancient rock, a high-pressure process is reshaping the modern energy landscape. As fracking expands across the globe, so does the growing debate around its impact. What is fracking? You may have heard about the effects this oil and gas extraction technique have on the environment, but its impacts extend far beyond that.Â Â  Between 2007 and 2016, oil production in the United States increasedÂ 75 percent, while natural gas production increâ€¦

entry.title: 7 unmissable UK beaches to visit this summer
entry.summary:
Somewhere in the UK's four nations, your perfect beach awaits. Across 7,700 miles of coastline spread between the four nations of the UK are family favourites, wildlife wonderlands, historical strands and bays of astonishing wild beauty. Here are seven of the best beaches to visit this summer.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Donâ€™t believe anyone who says the United Kingdom is a poor comparison to the likes of Australia, or South Africa when it comes to beaches. What the country lacks in palm trees or exotic wildlife, it makes up for in the sheer variety of its coastline. Somewhere in its four nations, your perfect beach awaits: places with birdlife or wild beauty and destinations where fish and chips with your feet in the sand is an essentiaâ€¦

entry.title: The 4 biggest mysteries the new Vera Rubin Observatory could solve
entry.summary:
On a mountaintop in Chile's sprawling Atacama Desert, a new telescope has turned its mechanical eyes to the heavens, stargazing with unprecedented intensity. The Vera C. Rubin Observatory will take hundreds of pictures, every night, for the next 10 years.
Astronomers around the world are absolutely giddy over Rubin, which is named for the late astronomer who discovered evidence for the existence of dark matter. The observatory's mirrors will collect a tremendous amount of light, catching the glint of very faint, faraway objects. That light will be focused into the largest digital camera on the planet, a 3,200-megapixel camera the size of an SUV, capable of producing pictures from multiple wavelengths of light.Â
Instead of focusing on one segment of sky for hours at a time, Rubin â€¦

entry.title: What makes the North Seaâ€™s waves so treacherous
entry.summary:
Sometimes, the North Sea just decides to take a shot at you. Henk Buitjes knows what itâ€™s like.
Once, it happened at night in rough weather. The Dutch shrimp fisher was hauling his nets aboard when out of the corner of his eye he saw the wave. It stood out. Bigger than all the others, it was about to hit the rear of his fishing ship, a beam trawler.
The wave smashed into one of the shipâ€™s two beams, long horizontal poles that hang over the side and suspend nets in the water.
The incredible force of the wave battered the unlucky beam. It bowed the beam, leaving the net hanging slack and almost impossible to retrieve. That, Buitjes knew, was extremely dangerous. The net might wrap itself around the shipâ€™s propeller or become ensnared on seabed debris.
He and his crew manaâ€¦

entry.title: What it's like to celebrate midsummer in Sweden
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As my Swedish army bike rattles down the last hill, I place a hand on the basket to secure my Midsummer contributions: two king-size sausage rolls and a green bean and orange salad. The wide-open fields of southern Swedenâ€™s fertile SÃ¶derslÃ¤tt plain, yellow with rapeseed flowers, stretch out to my right, while to my left, the Baltic Sea has just slipped out of sight, having been there for most of my 20-minute ride from the station.
When I turn into the gravel drive, Malin and Christianâ€™s century-old brick villa, KÃ¤llbacken, meaning â€˜hill with a springâ€™, is already clattering with preparations. Malin and her seven-year-old daughter Edith have been out picking the flowers and greenery that will decorate the midsommarâ€¦

entry.title: When 'Jaws' invaded Marthaâ€™s Vineyard, 50 years ago
entry.summary: Director Steven Spielberg on the set of Jaws. 50 years after the legendary movie was filmed, locals reminisce about the time Hollywood came to town. JAWS DIDN'T JUST CHANGE cinematic history. The summer blockbuster also transformed Marthaâ€™s Vineyard. Long before the Clintons, Obamas, Oprah, and Larry David moved in to make it the starriest second-home locale on the Eastern Seaboard, the tranquil New England island was everything Hollywood wasnâ€™t. In fact, prior to director Steven Spielberg and crew setting up cameras to create the definitive shark thriller, the last movie to shoot there was in the silent era. â€œJaws put us on the map,â€ explains Marthaâ€™s Vineyard Museum research librarian Bow Van Riper. â€œIt was what really kicked off the world coming to the Vineyard, and â€¦

entry.title: Celebrate Amsterdam's 750th birthday with these fun-filled events
entry.summary:
Amsterdamâ€™s â€˜dancing housesâ€™ get their nickname from the way they seem to sway and dance, creating an optical illusion. Twenty-four-hour neighbourhood festivals, a nine-mile-long street party and a whole year of revelry â€” Amsterdam is pulling out all the stops for its 750th birthday.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This year, Amsterdam marks its extraordinary 750-year journey from medieval fishing village to global cultural capital with a festival programme as dynamic and diverse as the city itself. Everyday spaces will be transformed in unexpected ways â€” on the longest day of the year, locals will reclaim the traffic-heavy A10 ring road for a nine-mile street party featuring culture, sport and even 20 weddings. Meanwhile, in late August, thâ€¦

entry.title: Ukraine: Security Council hears of escalating attacks, diplomatic developments
entry.summary: The UN Security Council met on Friday to discuss the situation in Ukraine, where intensified fighting continues, affecting new areas and prompting further displacement.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜A fire no one can controlâ€™: UN warns of spiralling Iran-Israel war
entry.summary: The world stands on the edge of catastrophe, United Nations Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres warned on Friday, as Israelâ€™s military campaign inside Iran intensifies and strikes on nuclear facilities threaten to trigger a catastrophe.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN Peacebuilding Commission â€˜more needed than everâ€™ amid rising conflict
entry.summary: Former Liberian President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf and other senior officials from across the world have spoken about how international support was critical to putting their countries on the path to peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WHO warns of a health financing emergency
entry.summary: The world is facing a health financing emergency, according to Dr. Kalipso Chalkidou, Director for Health Financing and Economics for the World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: For too long, â€˜unbound horrorsâ€™ have unfolded in Sudan
entry.summary: Hostilities continue to escalate across Sudanâ€™sÂ North Darfur andÂ Kordofan regions, with reports of civilian casualties, sexual violence, abductions and looting, the UN human rights chief warned on Friday, describing the consequences as disastrous.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: From Syria, UN refugee chief calls for greater solidarity with displaced people
entry.summary: Although record numbers of people â€“ over 122 million worldwide â€“ have been uprooted due to war, violence and persecution, their ability to find safety and support is threatened more than ever.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza horrors continue as the weakest succumb to injuries and disease
entry.summary: Death and suffering in Gaza are ever-present and the enclave's people now have little choice but to risk their lives to fetch aid supplies, UN agencies said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: MIDDLE EAST CRISIS: Live updates for 20 June
entry.summary: One week since the Israel-Iran conflict erupted, diplomatic efforts to end the war are ramping up in Geneva today as foreign ministers from France, Germany, the UK and the European Union prepare to meet their Iranian counterpart. In New York, meanwhile, the UN Security Council is also set to discuss this latest worrying escalation, against the backdrop of the ongoing emergency in Gaza. We'll be covering these developments and more across the UN system today. UN NewsÂ app users can follow here.

entry.title: World Refugee Day: telling their stories
entry.summary: Of the 122 million people globally displaced by persecution, violence or human rights violations, 42.7 million are refugees who have fled across borders, according to new data from the UN refugee agency (UNHCR).

entry.title: Long after the guns fall silent, conflict-related sexual violence leaves lasting scars
entry.summary: Sexual violence in conflict is a tactic of war, torture and terror. It does not only devastate survivors but also tears apart families and communities. The trauma, shame and stigma are borne by victims, not perpetrators â€“ echoing across generations.

entry.title: The Golden Records tell the story of Earth. Hereâ€™s what they say.
entry.summary:
The Golden Record carried by Voyager 1 and 2. Photographs of Jupiter by Voyager 1 on March 24, 1979 and Uranus by Voyager 2 on January 24, 1986. In 1977, NASA launched two 12-inch gold-plated copper disks filled with the sounds of children's laughter, heartbeats, and bird calls. Is their time in space running out?
In 1977, NASA launched Voyagers 1 and 2 from Cape Canaveral, Florida into space to embark on a grand tour of the far reaches of our solar system. Mounted on board each probe was a 12-inch gold-plated copper diskâ€”a cosmic â€œmessage in a bottleâ€ engraved with sights, sounds, and depictions of life on Earth, collectively known as the Golden Recordsâ€”on the slim chance some far-off alien civilization might discover them. And in Disney and Pixarâ€™s animated film Elio, in theatersâ€¦

entry.title: Were there sinister motives behind founding Liberia?
entry.summary:
Faced with injustice in the land of their enslavement, oppressed people might find the offer of a new country, with the chance for freedom and prosperity, attractive. During the early 1800s in the U.S., however, the idea of establishing a colony of Black Americans in Africa was deeply controversial among freedmenâ€”people of African descent who had gained freedom from enslavementâ€”and freeborn Black people.
The reasons centered on the self-serving motives of many of the projectâ€™s promoters: It was supported by, among others, pro-enslavement figures. Although it led to the founding of Liberiaâ€”the worldâ€™s second ever Black republicâ€”the new state later practiced violence against Indigenous Africans.
Most free Black people saw themselves as Americans, participating in the economy of tâ€¦

entry.title: Forget the road tripâ€”these national parks are best visited by train
entry.summary:
A passenger train rolls through the unforgiving desert landscape as seen through some beautiful blooming Ocotillo cactuses. Trains are an accessible way to see some of Americaâ€™s national parks. With popular national parks still searching for the answers to congestion, train travel is a practical solutionâ€”and a unique adventure.
Driving to and through the most popular U.S. national parks can be a hassleâ€”from parking to long lines at the entrance gates. For many parks, train travel may be the stress-free answer for parkgoers who donâ€™t want to drive. Locomotives can move hundreds of people along a rail bed less than 5 feet wide, which can drastically reduce traffic woes. Riders can enter these parks without a coveted vehicle reservation while enjoying vistas often inaccessible by roadâ€¦

entry.title: These dolphins have orca friendsâ€”but may have an ulterior motive
entry.summary:
Pacific white-sided dolphins swim off the coast of British Columbia. Dolphins and porpoises in this region have been spotted swimming alongside a population of killer whales known as northern resident orcas. Scientists have theories about why. Scientists have documented what might be the first case of friendly interactions between killer whales and smaller cetaceans. Here's what they think is going on.
A pod of Dallâ€™s porpoises sped toward an adult orca, swimming under and around her for a few minutes before getting â€œboredâ€ and moving on to her companionsâ€”a mother orca with a young calf. As soon as the porpoises appeared, the calf seems to have gotten excited, speeding up and trying to catch the porpoises. The mother eventually got frustrated, but â€œthe calf looked like it was havinâ€¦

entry.title: Thereâ€™s a deeper meaning behind Juneteenth food traditions
entry.summary:
Juneteenth is celebration of Black history and culture, where communities gather and eat, as seen here at a festival at Malcolm X Park in West Philadelphia. Grilled meats, watermelon, and hibiscus are often served on the holiday not only to bring communities together, but to honor Black history.
While now recognized as a national holiday, Juneteenth has always been embedded in the local culture of Galveston, Texas, where the last group of enslaved Africans were freed by Union soldiers two years after the Civil War ended. The holiday is still cherished among city locals who celebrate the day their ancestors were finally given their freedom.
(Juneteenth is Americaâ€™s second Independence Dayâ€”hereâ€™s why.)
At its core, Juneteenth represents the community coming together over muâ€¦

entry.title: This Reporter Exposed the Civilian Toll of US Airstrikes. Her Warning: Be Ready for a More Hostile World
entry.summary: The Pulitzer Prize winning investigative reporter Azmat Khan is known for her rigorous reporting on civilian casualties in war, the impact of US airstrikes, and for exposing systemic failures in military and government accountability.

entry.title: The unlikely comeback of Americaâ€™s most endangered songbird
entry.summary:
On the dry prairies of the Sunshine State, thereâ€™s a tiny, camouflaged bird known as the Florida grasshopper sparrow. Each one weighs about as much as three U.S. quarters yet has to survive against a backdrop of torrential floods, herds of stomping cattle, and waves of ravenous fire ants.
Not to mention the humans. â€œWeâ€™ve lost over 90 percent of their habitat,â€ saysÂ Fabiola â€œFabbyâ€ Baeza-Tarin, a senior conservation ecologist with a Tampa-based consulting firm known as Common Ground Ecology.Â
Florida grasshopper sparrows and many other organisms rely on the dry prairie for their entire life cycles, not even leaving to migrate, but humans have increasingly rendered the space inhabitable by clearing and draining it to make way for development, ranching, and intensified agricultâ€¦

entry.title: This is the first ever confirmed skull of a Denisovan
entry.summary:
The "Dragon Man" skull was discovered in Harbin, China in 1933 by a local laborer, but remained hidden away until 2018. A new analysis now finds its very likely to be a Denisovan. Finally, we can put a face on a Denisovan.
In the summer of 2021, a team of five Chinese researchers stirred up some controversy by suggesting that an unusual skull unearthed in northeastern China belonged to a previously unknown species they thereby officially described as Homo longi, nicknamed â€œDragon Man.â€ (Both names were inspired by the Long Jiang Dragon River region where it was found.) Soon afterwards, the team was contacted by paleogeneticist Qiaomei Fu of the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology in Beijing, who asked if she could try and get DNA from the skull.Â Â
Back â€¦
